ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: A field trip would have been a nice addition. Question 9 inspired this comment.

#10 I want to have a career doing environmental justice work and this class was perfect for me. It gave me a theoretical basis in which to work with and the final projects introduced me to the breadth of environmental health. I have used both the theoretical concepts learned in this class and examples of the breadth of environmental justice when speaking with employers and networking with colleagues. It's a wonderful course and one that will have growing relevance in the future as disparities become more pronounced.
This is a social science course. Don't expect to talk about real world change in its own context.

I felt frustrated with the quality of the readings and the quality of the lectures. This is such an important course, and it's unique at FES, but I think it needs to be more rigorous. For example, if we are going to talk about what justice means, we should read some of the philosophical giants instead of referring casually to them in lecture. There could be a really deep and powerful philosophical and ethical underpinning to the case study explorations that we do later in the semester--this would enhance our understanding of different scenarios AND make us more powerful advocates for advancing justice.

The professor led lectures could have gone more in depth. I would have liked to be challenged more by the material the professor brought to the class. She did an excellent job explaining the material that she brought, but I want more.
A mix of student- and instructor-generated content.

The class really forced me to think about the application of environmental justice in multiple disciplines. The course really forced me to define environmental justice in my own context and in the context of other people's frameworks. This is very important as EJ means many different things to many different people. Being able to understand EJ from others' standpoints in central to advancing EJ in the US and worldwide.

I really enjoyed the opportunity to discuss EJ issues with my classmates. I think these sorts of topics don't get covered very much in other courses on offer at FES, so it was good to have a forum for that.The opportunity to create our own case studies and present them to the class was great because I needed to practise my presentation skills, and also because I relished the freedom of picking my own topic and pursuing the research independently. It was also great hearing other people's presentations because everyone spoke about topics they were personally interested in and passionate about.

I learned a lot from classmates' case studies, but I think that student work took up too much of the semester. Perhaps instead of devoting an entire seminar to one group's project, the course could condense a few into a single session. This way there would be more time in the semester for digging deeper into issues and exploring more literature.
Developing a basic literacy in various environmental topics with a strong justice element.

Having the liberty to choose a topic that I was interested and really thoroughly research it, and present it to the class. I was able to learn a lot about a specific topic, as well as other topics the rest of the class was researching. I like the structure of the class and was able to learn a lot from it.
Freedom to complete the final assignment in a way and on a topic that interests the student.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Nothing. I am contemplating sitting in next year to listen to the discussions, if allowed.
perhaps we could have some speakers in the class who do EJ work. There are plenty of groups in CT and NYC.

The course in general doesn't need much improvement. Perhaps more connection to EJ issues in our immediate environment would have been good - maybe through having people come and speak who're involved in EJ issues in New Haven, or doing a walking tour around EJ sites nearby (like the EJAY student groups organised).

Amity is really smart and interesting and willing to listen, but it's hard to articulate what I got out of this course. I know that Amity is sympathetic to students' interest in this class being more oriented to the "real world," and I have trouble believing that the academic review board could be SO insistent that it be grounded in social science theories.

In general I felt that discussions were too unstructured and went on too long. The lectures at the beginning of seminar didn't provide enough meat for a rich discussion. I would have like to go into greater depth with different issues. In a way, this class echoes the Linkages of Sustainability class--it introduces problems that are, essentially, impossible to bound. One problem is linked to a problem or a demand elsewhere, such that you are constantly confronted with the highly complex interconnectedness of systems. The class would have benefited from exposure to systems literature, or social network literature, or political economy literature--more foundational material in which to ground problems, beyond just thehistory of the EJ movement.

I wish the course challenged me and my thinking more. I think the instructor also could have pushed us more to think about why justice issues are relevant.... whether through a framework of ethics or environmental impact, etc.
Depth of knowledge and understanding brought to the class

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both were very responsive and helpful. I think the class was really synergetic and the benefits were often mutual between the students, TA and instructor.
Erica was great. Thank you for breakfast!
I didn't ask for help very much, but when I did I got all I needed - no problems to report
Both were helpful and responsive.
both very easy to connect with and communicate with. Amity really makes an effort to be available to students, and is really helpful in one-on-one meetings.
Very good in terms of both availability and quality, for both the instructor and the TA.
Both were great.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I'm a public health student studying environmental health. Prior to taking this class I only understood EJ in the context of health effects and cumulative impacts and health disparities. This class just opened my eyes to the other parts of EJ--the economic injustices the come about from land degradation, as well as the climate justice and the plight of indigenous peoples and their lands.

I am interested in environmental governance so this course was really valuable for highlighting environmental issues from a justice perspective, and learning about how different communities can become marginalised or privileged through the implementation (or not) of particular policies. I think every environmental practitioner should think about these issues at least onceduring their careers, and preferably on a regular basis.

In my first year at FES, and through my field work, I came to realize that essentially all environmental issues are justice issues, and I wished to explore degradation and exploitation through the lens of equity and human dignity.
Although it is tangentially related, I believe justice is something that should be considered by anyone doing environmental work.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To get a broader view of environmental justice and to hone my own ideas about EJ.
See answer to Question 15 above
see above.
Interest in the ethical/moral considerations of conservation

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Exceeded.
Exceeded!
Yes

not quite. I'd like a deeper fluency in the philosophy of justice, in the legal and economic and political structures that pave the way for injustice, and models for change and triumph. It did, however, help me to start having more conversations, in my daily life, about the human implications of different choices, behaviors, systems, structures, norms, etc. I would have liked to learn more about organizing, empowerment, alternative models of political action, etc.

Yes, it was a great class. It was difficult to get a routine going in terms of work load because the course only meets once a week. The class sometimes felt long, and thought it might be better if we met twice a week instead.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: More
I got more than I expected!
Yes - and more - I hadn't expected to learn so much from my fellow classmates
I had vague expectations...
Yes, I learned so much in this course, the readings were all very interesting. I thought the course material was a good combination of scholarly, academic articles and mainstream news articles.
Yes, I gained an excellent vocabulary to talk about EJ issues and a framework for understanding how the issues progress.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group had complementary skills and lots of commitment.

The advantages of groups work are 1)the group provides critical feedback to my ideas, thereby making me a stronger student and 2) the group provides a diversity of opinions and perspectives which is enriching.
I'm glad that we got to choose our groups and that we could choose how integrated or separate our projects were. Having a two-part project was very frustrating though.

Great working team. I learned somuch from my collaborator. It was a challenge to do such a big team project (worked on it all semester, devoted a lot of class time to presentation/discussion), but ultimately really rewarding.
It was helpful to bounce ideas off of one another, and to work on making conceptual connections between distinct topics.

It was great to work with a partner for our final project. We were able to offer different perspectives and bring different ideas to the table about our subject matter. It was great and worked out really well.
The group work was excellent. The work was evenly split, and my partner brought a very different perspective and strategy that melded well with my own and expanded the breadth of our project.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You will get out ofthis class what you put into it.
Be open. EJ is a morphing concept; be open to expanding your ideas of it.
Go for it!

Get into the Greeks, the old spiritual thinkers, the humanists that speak and write so eloquently on why human dignity matters and what constitutes justice. Think outside of the readings and come ready to generate discussion and ask provocative questions in class, because often there is a lot of time left by the seminar structure for conversation.
